caseTitle: MISCELLANY-AT-LAW DURBAR OF ATTORNEYS [1989-90] VOL. XVII RG
summary: The 1989 Durbar of Attorneys, organized by the PNDC Acting Attorney-General Mr. Tanoh, served as an annual forum for assessing the performance of the Attorney-General’s Department and addressing systemic challenges. Deputy Secretary for Justice Martin A. B. K. Amidu delivered a written address highlighting critical issues such as inadequate logistics, deteriorating library facilities, and insufficient office resources, particularly affecting regional offices. He emphasized the attorney's role in national economic recovery, advocating for law as a tool of social engineering aligned with government policy. Amidu criticized substandard legal work, including improper pleading practices, and called for a continuing legal education system and periodic performance assessments. He lamented the decline in mentorship of junior attorneys and urged a return to rigorous training traditions to restore professional excellence and public confidence.
citations: MISCELLANY-AT-LAW: DURBAR OF ATTORNEYS [1989-90] VOL. XVII RGL 19–31
rationaleHighlights: Law must be purposively used as a tool for social and economic transformation.
Attorneys must align their work with government policy objectives in a developmental state.
Substandard legal work undermines the integrity of the legal profession.
Mentorship of junior attorneys is essential for institutional capacity building.
Continuing legal education should be institutionalized to maintain professional standards.
Prerogative writs like certiorari and prohibition cannot be sought via ordinary civil pleadings.
The state attorney has a duty to serve government policy after conscientious acceptance of employment.
Regional legal offices face disproportionate challenges affecting service delivery.
confidenceNotes: High confidence in factual extraction; content is based on a published address at an official durbar with clear attribution. Some interpretive legal themes are derived from the speaker's jurisprudential views.
